content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Search for the most recent paper related to non-commutative geometry submitted by an author with the first name John. Provide the title and the abstract.  Please interact with https://arxiv.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To search for the most recent paper on non-commutative geometry by an author named John, I need to use the search box at the top. I should enter keywords like "non-commutative geometry John" to maximize the chances of matching both the topic and the author's first name. The appropriate element for the search term is the textbox labeled [4].
Action: Type [4]; non-commutative geometry John
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The previous search returned no results. The guidelines below the search highlight that for best results, I should search author's names in the "Author(s)" field, using the format "surname, forename" (e.g., "Smith, John") or searching for "John" in the Author(s) field. I should use Advanced Search to specify the topic in the title/abstract and the author's first name in the Author(s) field.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To refine the search using Advanced Search, I should separate the topic "non-commutative geometry" and the author name "John" using the correct fields. I should add another term for Author(s), put "John" in that field, and ensure "non-commutative geometry" is in the title/abstract search.
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Now there are two searchable fields. I need to update the first field to search for "non-commutative geometry" in the Title/Abstract (not All fields), and use the second textbox for the author's first name. I should clear the first box and enter "non-commutative geometry".
Action: Type [12]; non-commutative geometry
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The query returned no results, likely because I searched "non-commutative geometry" in all fields or too restrictively. I should use the advanced search again, explicitly separating the topic and author in their respective fields: put "non-commutative geometry" in Title/Abstract and "John" into the Author(s) field, using "Refine query" to return to the advanced form.
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to add a second search box for the author. I should click "Add another term +" to create this field, then specify "John" and set the field to Author(s).
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The second search term field has been added. I need to type "John" in this new field and then change the corresponding dropdown to "Author(s)" instead of "Title".
Action: Type [17]; John
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The query returned no results, possibly because "John" was searched in the "Title" field instead of "Author(s)." I need to refine the search and specify "Author(s)" for the second field to search for papers where John is an author.
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The second search term textbox includes "John," but the dropdown next to it is still set to "Title." I need to change this dropdown to "Author(s)" so the system searches for papers authored by someone with the first name John.
Action: Click [17]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown menu with search-field options is open, and I need to select "Author(s)" for the field associated with "John" to ensure the search includes papers authored by someone named John.
Action: Click [17] (select "Author(s)" from the dropdown)
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown menu for the search field next to "John" is still visible and currently set to "Title". I need to select "Author(s)" from the dropdown to specify that "John" should be in the author field, and then run the search.
Action: Click [17] (select "Author(s)")
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown menu for the search field associated with "John" is currently open and set to "Title." I need to select "Author(s)" from the dropdown to specify that "John" should appear as an author.
Action: Click [17] (choose "Author(s)")
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.85

Observation: please analyze the attached screenshot and give the Thought and Action. I've provided the tag name of each element and the text it contains (if text exists). Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.

content:
Thought: The dropdown menu for the second search term ("John") is now closed and can be set. I need to click the "Search" button to perform the query with "non-commutative geometry" in Title and "John" in Author(s).
Action: Click [19]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.9

Observation: please analyze the attached screenshot and give the Thought and Action. I've provided the tag name of each element and the text it contains (if text exists). Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.
[1]: "member institutions";	[2]: "Donate";	[4]: <input> "Search term or terms";	[5]: "Help";	[6]: "Advanced Search";	[7]: "All fields Title Author Abstract Comments Journal reference ACM classification MSC classification Report number arXiv identifier DOI ORCID arXiv author ID Help pages Full text", "Field to search";	[8]: <button> "Search";	[9]: "Login";	[10]: "Search v0.5.6 released 2020-02-24";	[11]: "order: -announced_date_first; size: 50; include_cross_list: True; terms: AND all=non-commutative geometryConfidence: 0.97; AND title=JohnConfidence: 0.99";	[12]: "Refine query";	[13]: "New search";	[14]: "Simple Search";	[15]: "About";	[16]: "Help";	[17]: "Contact";	[18]: "Subscribe";	[19]: "Copyright";	[20]: "Privacy Policy";	[21]: "Web Accessibility Assistance";	[22]: "arXiv Operational Status";	[23]: "email";	[24]: "slack";

content:
Thought: The search returned no results. This may be due to using only "John" as the author, which may be too broad, or because "non-commutative geometry" doesn't match any recent papers by any author named John. To widen the search, I can try using "noncommutative geometry" (no dash) or search in "All fields." Alternatively, I could try just "noncommutative" in the title and "John" in authors to broaden the scope.
Action: Click [12] (Refine query)
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.9

content:
Thought: To broaden the search, I should try searching for "noncommutative geometry" (without the dash) in All fields, as this may match papers even if "non-commutative" is spelled differently. Alternatively, searching just "noncommutative" could further increase the matches. I will update the first search box to "noncommutative geometry", ensure the field is set to "All fields", and keep "John" for Author(s).
Action: Type [12]; noncommutative geometry
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.92
